content: Compose a one-sentence definition of the Banach-Tarski Paradox that not only outlines the counterintuitive concept of being able to split a solid ball into a finite number of pieces and reassemble them into two balls of the same size, but also provides an example of how this paradox has been utilized in modern mathematical or scientific research.

The Banach-Tarski Paradox states that it is possible to decompose a solid ball into a finite number of non-measurable pieces and reassemble them into two identical copies of the original ball, a concept that, while counterintuitive, has inspired advancements in the field of geometric group theory, particularly in exploring the properties of groups and their actions on spaces.
